A simple mount for the FatShark 600TVL and PZ0420M camera for the Mini Tricopter. The PZ0420M only comes in the 7 degree tilt variant as it needs to be tilted to fit. For the FatShark there are 2 mount options:
  • No Tilt - Has no up tilt added to the camera. This is best if you're just getting into FPV or if you like your horizon to be in the center of your image at hover. However this will mean that you're looking at more ground when you're in forward flight. You should also note that using this option the camera lens will not be centered in the opening in the frame. This is because it needs additional clearance up top so that the battery tray can fit.
  • 7 Degree Tilt - This option has 7 degrees of up tilt to the camera. This means that in a hover you're looking at more sky and it will have the feeling that you're tilted backwards. I would not recommend this if you're new to FPV. However if you're racing or doing a lot of fast forward flight then this one is for you!
    • Provided in the files section is a drill guide which you can use to drill a 3mm (1/8") hole in an existing bottom frame. If you don't already have a frame printed up it will be stronger if you use the provided bottom frame that has the hole already in it. This way the hole has some support around it rather than just the infill and a couple of solid layers. Either way you'll need a M3x5 or 6mm bolt to attach it to the copter. You'll also need a small zip tie to attach the camera to the mount. Enjoy!
    Jared

title: Bezier curves and knots script for Blender

description.text:
This is a Python script that I've been working on for Blender, to generate 3D geometry based on bezier curves. My goal is to produce a variety of attractive and accurate Celtic knots and braids to use as artistic elements in my projects. I developed a customizable picture frame as a testbench for my work. You can use it as a stand-alone project to generate a picture frame with text (or without).
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54020 Adding Celtic knot elements to that, my Celtic Picture Frame is an early result of these experiments.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55464 I have more ideas and enhancements that I hope to share later. The script is is in a usable state now, so give it a try! UPDATE: 2012 Mar 6 -- version 1.1. uploaded to fix bugs in the utility function ReadCurveControls()

You will use the script file "blender bezier rev1.py" in Blender. It is freely available at:
http://www.blender.org
Blender is highly sophisticated, professional-grade, 3D modeling and animation software. It is absolutely amazing -- one of the best software packages I have ever used. But please expect to spend some time learning to use it. There are many excellent tutorials and manuals on the Blender web site, and on YouTube. Open the Python ".py" file in a Blender text editor window and press "Run Script". This will produce bezier curve objects and mesh objects based on the curves. Modify the script to create new curve geometries, or use Blender object modifiers to adjust the results. Edit "controlPoints" to change the shape of the curves. Add, remove or relocate points, and control handles. Edit taperControl and BezierCircle lists to change the curve shaping. The script hides the source objects and creates meshes based on them. Use File->export to save selected objects as an STL file. After editing curve nodes in Blender, use the ReadCurveControls function to dump the control values -- you can use them to update your script. Please send bug fixes and enhancements.

description.text:
Portrait Bust of the Emperor Hadrian Marble
Roman, Hadrianic period
ca. A.D. 118-120
Found in Hadrian's villa at Tibur (modern Tivoli, near Rome) This bust shows Hadrian in the early part of his reign, when his beard was still relatively short and his face had a serene expression. Romans generally shaved off their beards when they reached maturity in their mid-twenties. Hadrian was the first emperor to continue to wear one and so started a fashion that persisted in imperial portraiture until the time of Constantine in the early fourth century. Hadrian's choice to remain bearded was influenced in part by his love of Greek culture, in which beards traditionally signified wisdom and maturity. Scanned at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
NYC Cleaned up, holes patched, and base generated in Modo.

author: damian3d

title: Itty Bitty Double Extruder (with mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3v)

description.text:
UPDATE: a hardware kit is now available! click here I am proud to present the Itty Bitty Double Extruder, a two-material belt-driven extruder with mounting hardware for MakerFarm i3v printers. Versions are provided for 3mm and 1.75mm filament. The extruder should be easily mountable on any printer that can accept a standard Hinged Accessible Extruder. Features:
  • For Original Hexagon hot ends on 20mm centers (NOTE: NOT Hexagon AO)
  • NEMA 14 motors
  • GT2 belt drives with printed pulleys
  • Integrated servo Z probe
  • Cam-lock idler bearing pins
  • Uses standard hobbed bolts available here
  • 2mm narrower and 2g lighter than the stock MakerFarm extruder
  • Includes mounts for Prusa i3v with integrated hot end cooling
    • Discussion thread: http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?8848-Itty-Bitty-Double-Extruder See the instructions for a list of vitamins. Note: You will want to use firmware that will lift the Z axis when deploying and stowing the probe to keep it from hitting the bed. If you're using Marlin, you may wish to check out this thread: http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?6165-Marlin-firmware-fork-for-MakerFarm-i3v-w-auto-bed-level-amp-Roxy-s-enhancements

Detailed, step-by-step assembly and calibration instructions can be found here: http://clough42.com/instructions/ibde-assembly/ Files are provided for 3mm and 1.75mm versions of the extruder. You can print all of the pieces separately, or you can print the provided plates of multiple parts. You will need to print:
  • IttyBittyDoublePlate1.STL
  • IttyBittyDoublePlate2-1.75mm.STL or IttyBittyDoublePlate2-3mm.STL
  • Two copies of Parametric-Pulley-80-8-hex.STL (these will fit on Plate 1 if your printer can print a whole bed of parts cleanly without oozing or warping)
    • In addition to the printed parts, you will need the following vitamins:
  • Hobbed bolts with nuts (2)
    • Available here: http://clough42.com/go/product/hobbed-extruder-bolt/
  • Hexagon hot ends (NOTE: NOT Hexagon AO) (2)
  • NEMA 14 stepper motors (2)
    • Available here: http://clough42.com/go/product/nema-14-stepper-motor
  • HXT-900 servo available here
  • Z probe switch
  • 25x25x10mm Fan
    • for hexagon cooling
    • recommended: http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?KeyWords=259-1570-ND
  • 40mm fan
    • for print cooling
  • RAMPS fan extender
    • if using software fan on RAMPS
  • Stepper driver
    • if your RAMPS board only has four
  • Hardware kit available here:
    • GT2 20-tooth Pulleys with set screws (2)
    • GT2 200mm Belts (2)
    • 688ZZ 8x16x5mm Bearings (6)
    • Extension springs (2)
    • Fiberglass/Polyimide insulator
    • M2.5x10 socket head cap screws (2)
    • M4x.7 hex nuts (2)
    • M4x20 button head cap screws (2)
    • M3 flat washers (6)
    • M3x.5 hex nuts (11)
    • M3x25 socket head cap screws (3)
    • M3x16 button head socket cap screws (10)
    • M3x12 flat head socket cap screws (10)
    • M3x8 socket head cap screws (6)
    • M3x6 button head socket cap screws (2)
    • Assembly notes:
  • Heat new Hexagon hot ends to temperature and tighten both the nozzle and the down tube into the heat block before installing in the printer. If you do not do this, they will leak.
  • Remove the support material from the bottom of the filament channels
  • You can install the double groove mount either side up, depending on how your printer bridges the bottom of the hot end pockets. It should hold the hot ends firmly and be flush to the bottom of the block.
  • The 25mm fan should be installed with the air blowing up (drawing air in over the hot ends)
  • Make an insulator with some fiberglass and Kapton tape to install above the hot end heat blocks. If you don't the hot end cooling shroud will melt.
  • You can feed all of the wires up through the channel in the center of the block. Force in some scraps of 3mm filament and zip tie as a strain relief.
  • You will need to orient the heat blocks properly for the wires and Z probe to clear. See photos.
  • You may need to adjust your X carriage so the extruder tips are at the same height. As long as you're using auto-bed-leveling, you can usually get enough adjustment by turning one of the Z motors by hand to tilt the whole X axis.

comments.text: There is a 25mm fan behind the extruder that draws air in the front, over the hot ends to cool them.  Hexagon hot ends require constant cooling air to maintain a sharp heat break and prevent jamming.
comments.author: bakefy

comments.text: First, this is amazing.  The design is unreal and I can't wait to get this running. I just have one question, what do you have covering the bottoms of your hot ends?  Did you print those covers?  I can't tell if it's actually just the bottom of the hot end or a cover.
comments.author: Gogonjdevil

comments.text: The last batch of hot ends I ordered came with those covers.  I think RRD calls them isolators.  They keep stray plastic from building up on the hot end, and they insulate the hot end so the temp doesn't drop as much when the print cooling fan kicks on.
comments.author: Gogonjdevil

comments.text: Thanks for the quick response. Where did you order your Hot Ends from?  I want to make sure mine have them too as I've always had a problem with plastic building up on the hot end.

comments.text: I just confirmed today that all hot ends in stock at MakerFarm now have the rubber isolators.

comments.text: If you're running auto-bed-leveling, you can just rack the whole X carriage or level the bed to the nozzles, as long as they aren't too far off.  The procedure is here:
comments.author: tstockgl

comments.text: That worked out great!  Your calibration documentation was extremely helpful.  No need for shims, as the height difference between hot ends was able to be adjusted as you described.  I am now just trying to get my Slic3r settings adjusted to avoid cross contamination between filaments...
comments.author: clough42

comments.text: Just an Update:
comments.author: tstockgl

comments.text:
First off, great design, both form and function! I got it up and running over the weekend and it's working great! Just have the print fan left to install.
My question is regarding the servo for the auto bed leveling and the RAMPS fan extender co-existing. I'm wondering how you have your servo connected when the fan extender takes up all the servo ports?
Any advice would be appreciated!
Thanks!
Tyson
comments.author: tstockgl

comments.text: I cheated.  The RAMPS Fan Extender fits over all four sets of servo pins, but it only uses the last two.  So the first servo connector, where the Z probe servo should be is covered, but not used.  I just soldered a 3-pin connector to the top of the fan extender board to pass the signals through, and I plug the servo in there.
comments.author: tstockgl

comments.text: Just got it working the way you described.  My soldering isn't very pretty but it's doing the job! Thanks for the tip!
comments.author: clough42

comments.text: Note that I think this only works with the RRD fan extender.  The Geetech extender seems to be wired on D11/D6 instead of D4/D5.  I'm still investigating that.
comments.author: tstockgl

comments.text: An update...the Geetech extender uses the first two servo connectors, so you can just shift it two pins to the right, so it's plugged into D4/D5 only and you can control two fans while leaving D11 open for your ABL servo.
comments.author: clough42

I only modelled this to make an interlocking part.

title: Stanley Tool Organizer Side Panel Separators with Drawers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For my "Stanley Tool Organizer System" (Amazon Link) I made some separators with drawers for one of the side panels. There's a lot of space in there, but I rather use this toolbox for storing my carcassonne-tiles and meeples rather than for tools actually, because they just fit perfectly in there. For my usecase it's a waste of space to leave the side as is, so here's my solution:
separators! unfortunately the few upright walls are not that straight and stiff, but rather wobbly, so the drawers may not fit perfectly, but it works good enought for me. In case the separators dont fit with your printer (they should have a tight fit) i also added the scad file. it's a bit ugly ant not fully parametric, but it works for smaller adjustments. have fun and leave me a comment.

prints well with:

  • nozzle: .5
    layers: .3
    speed: 60mm/s
    infill: 20%

There aren't any designs, only photos.  I had a scanner that was... too old to be useful, sadly, which I got last year at Salvation Army for $5.  As an instructional lesson, I take things apart now and look at how they're designed, for organization, structure, efficiency, etc, so I can make better parts on the Makerbot.  
Flatbed scanners have a few neat parts in them, like buttons, gears, pulleys, belts, ribbons, guide bars for Z-stage mods, and usually a cold-cathode tube for illumination, or in newer models, probably an LED light source.  So I saved the light in this one, recycled everything else, and figured I'd try to hook it up.

!!!I AM NOT AN ELECTRICIAN, NOR AM I VERY SMART.  If you know how to do these things properly, please comment below.  I hold no responsibility if you set fire to your cat or Makerbot!!!
I don't know where I read it on the webs, but I had the impression cold-cathode tubes were lit using a transformer that converted approx. 5-12v DC into something that made it happy.  When you take apart a scanner, watch for a very tiny PCB with a hunky little transformer on it, which should be its own part separate from the main control boards.  SAVE THIS, and its connecting cable too. 
Be very careful removing the tube from the unit -- they're pretty fragile, and will break easily if removed improperly.  Don't disconnect the wires on either end, and it's best to leave the lamp itself in whatever holder or reflector it is housed in, which will help protect it.
In this case, I ran a free mini-Molex cable from my power supply (yellow = 12v, black = ground) to the positive and negative inputs on the transformer to the lamp.  I honestly can't say if they're polarized one way or the other, because the board doesn't tell me.  Just make sure you cover up any connectors you have free as you try it out.  If you wire it one way and no light appears, shut it off quickly and try another configuration... I have no idea if this stuff explodes or not. 
You may also need to run extension wires to the lamp itself from the transformer.  If you do so, try to mind your polarity back to the unit, and DO NOT leave your wires uncovered.  My electrical tape flipped open and I bridged the two wires going to the lamp... It didn't hurt as much as 350v capacitors, but it did cook my skin and it smelled like burning hair in my office for 30 minutes.  Don't do that.
Anyhow, since I have it wired to my power supply, any time the Makerbot is on, the light is on!  I'm going to try two other configurations at some point, using a second lamp if I can find one, and placing them vertically instead of at the top of the unit.  This should improve the light and how it is cast into the 'bot.  I like it tho, and it's pretty and better than my stupid desk lamp.  Good luck!

title: Safe and secure Raspberry Pi A+ Case

description.text:
Here comes the third member of the safe and secure Raspberry Pi family of cases. This one is for the Raspberry Pi A+ v1.1 board. Like its other brothers, it has been designed with very tight clearances, .2 and .3 mm to be exact. It is made to use four M3 16mm socket head screws with nuts to fasten the case together. You can find the other cases here: Case for the original Raspberry Pi B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209100 Case for the Raspberry Pi B+:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423216 Raspberry Pi 3 & 2 B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797 Enjoy!

This is the setup I used
.35 mm j-head
.25 mm layer height
125% for first layer
80% rectilinear in-fill
Fan always on except for first layer
2 vertical perimiters
2 bottom layers
2 top layers
This case was designed for .25 mm layer height.
Print a bottom and a top part without support.
Use 4x M3 16mm hex head to fasten.

My rear foglight on my PT Cruiser was ruined during a small crash. I printed out the outside of the light. I used a red transluzent PLA filament. The permeability of the light is a little less than the original one, but still much more brighter than the rear lights of the car, so the function as a fog light is given.   
This part is just the outside of the light, you have to glue it down to the chassis of the light. I used also silicone after the glue dried, to waterproof the light.  
saved 200 bucks :) if somebody has the same problem, maybe this cheap solution will help you out.

Use transluzent PLA red filament, 0.1 layer hight  
My printarea was to small to print out the whole light, so I made two smaler parts. If you are printing the two sections of the light use ChryslerFOG1 and Chrysler FOG2 and the small sections  ChryslerFOG-Conjunction-Outside and Inside to glue it together. If you have a bigger printbed just print the one piece ChyslerFOG  
Good Luck !

This is a reverse engineered fully customizable version/enhancement of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52386, the FlexiRoast Wooden Pen Stand from the Fablab Zurich. Reverse engineered to a customizable version by AndrÃ© from the Funlab Zurich.
Tested with plywood using current 2013 version of OpenSCAD.

Either download one of the precustomized .dxf files for 3 or 4mm plywood or better create your personally sized penholder by downloading the .scad file and change the penholder's setup parameters.
// Laser beam characteristics
LaserBeamDiameter = 0.23; // Value applies to the funlab laser
// Material characteristic
MaterialThickness = 3.2; // Material thickness // Objects dimensions and other settings
Height = 115; // Height of each of the 4 rastered and curved sides
Width = 65; // Width of each of the 4 rastered and curved sides
// The resulting size of the pen holder will appear in the console
// when Process = 1
ToothWidth = 5; // Conditions the computed number of teeth on the joint
StudW = 5; // Width of bottom/top studs/teeth
Dis = 5; // Distance between the exported parts put in place for cutting
// Flexibility settings
Ratio = 0.5; // Ratio of flexible raster to side width. The flexible raster
// is positioned in the middle of the width
SlotLength = 30; // Conditions the number of raster slots for flexibility
SlotWidth = 0.5; // Width of a raster slot
SlotDist = 2; // Distance between 2 rows of raster slots
// Type of operation to perform
Process = 0; // 0 = export parts in view of producing a .dxf file (F6)
// 1 = verify all settings published in the console log For a start it is best to change only the following 4 parameters: LaserBeamDiameter = 0.23; // Value applies to the funlab laser
MaterialThickness = 4.0; // Material thickness
Height = 115; // Height of each of the 4 rastered and curved sides
Width = 65; // Width o Smaller pen stands are more difficult to assemble than bigger ones. The downloadable .dxf files have been created for 3mm and 4mm plywood cut with a laser beam width of 0.23mm. The pen holders heights are 115mm and 75mm. If your laser has a different beam width, use openscad to generate a matching .dxf file. If you increase the setting of the beam width in OpenSCAD to a value higher than the real beam width of the laser, the parts will be harder to fit, if you lower the value below its real beam width, the parts tend to be loose. You can play with the beam with and cut out two fitting parts only and then test. If correctly set, you do not need any glue to hold the pieces together.
The easyest way to put the parts together, is, to assemble the 4 side parts (leaving the last side open), put them on a table and then add the bottom and the top part into the slots of one side and then stretch and fit the hull around the corners until finally closing the last side. Do not overstretch the flexible part or it will brake.
Hanspeter and AndrÃ© from the funlab zurich.

author: 3DTOD

title: iPhone5/4 in Otterbox Defender + Anker Astro E3 "Ingress Pack"

description.text: Added team logo(s) to the side; Enlightened (gee, wonder which team I'm on...) shown. I was nice, and made a Resistance version too, I just don't plan on printing one... I was also having a problem with one end of the battery retainer lifting off the print bed (always the same end, so maybe my heat bed has a cool spot?) -- so I made bigger "ears" to hold it down; that did the trick. This will also fit an iPhone 4 in an Otterbox Defender case (the width is basically the same); it will just be a little shorter than the battery, and this is a short cable: http://www.amazon.com/Innovative-Digital-Charge-compatible-iPhone/dp/B00DCRX9WE
Update:
Added Ingress logo; make sure to use the "logo_clip" .stl file.

If you play Ingress (https://www.ingress.com), you most likely have an external battery... So, I created a clip that piggybacks an Anker battery (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009USAJCC) with an iPhone 5 in an Otterbox Defender case. The clip latches onto the top edge of the case, and snaps into the notch on the other side of the case, just like the original belt clip. In fact, the entire combination can still be clipped into the Otterbox belt clip. Combined with a 10cm lightning cable (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B5RGAWY) and some bluetooth headphones, it makes a nice self contained package. There is a slot running the length of the back for inserting a "velcro cable tie" through, forming a simple wrist strap (more of a back-of-the-hand strap). Thanks to my friend, Carl, for that suggestion.

You will want to print one "clip", and one "battery retainer. There are 4 different clip files to choose from (of course, you should print #3):
  • The original (plain)
  • With the Ingress logo
  • With Ingress & Enlightened logos
  • With Ingress & Resistance logos
    • The main clip should be printed as-is (orientation), with support. The two "ears" should be cut away after printing; they help keep it stuck to the print bed (it doesn't have a large contact footprint, and the one "end" tends to want to lift). The battery retainer also has ears to keep it stuck to the print bed that should be removed after printing. It fits into the slot on the main clip, and should snap into place (bumps on the inside edges snap into recesses in the edges of the main clip; they may need some scraping/cleanup it's pretty tight tolerances). I used a 13" velcro cable tie (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004C4U1HC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1), any longer, and to would be too long. An 8" one should work.

I never expected my office to smell like a wood shop with the scent of freshly cut pine in the air, but that is exactly what happened today, thanks to the fine folks at colorfabb and, to honor the occasion, I tweaked the Pregnant Woman model to better suit the medium, mostly through giving it a thicker body. The picture fails to do her justice: in person this looks like it has been carved or cut from wood, not extruded from a 3d printer. The texture and general feel proclaim it as a wooden object. Even the layering somehow seems a natural part of the piece.

The most successful prints with the wood filament have been at 220 degrees. I have done both 0.2mm and 0.3mm layers and with 10% and 100% fill. I prefer the 100% fill, but the others have been fine.  
The main issue has been build up of filament on the nozzle. In this particular print it clumped, burned a bit, and fell onto the model. Luckily, I was able to snake it out with a tool before the print head got in the way. I've tried varying temperature and speed, but so far I have been unsuccessful in eliminating the issue.

There is no need anymore for taking the tube out of fridge... fiddling with unscrewing... and screwing back of the cap.  
Easy Squeeze is a simple and innovative product, made out of three parts which makes it easy for 3D printing. The product makes the regular mayonnaise tube, or any other similar tube, easy to use directly in the fridge; by simply pressing down the plastic part, which goes through the tube, with only two fingers. Other benefit of this product is that after you finish your tube, you will be sure you used everything from inside, which wasn't the case when you used it by your hands.

comments.text: I printed the 5 and 10mm cubes. The 5mm cube printed fine but I had to adjust settings for my printrbot because it could not cool fast enough and had problems with warping due to shrinkage at the top and not filling the top. First I adjusted to 50% fill which worked. I also tried lowering the fill back down to 15% and slowed the print speed to 15mm/sec from 45mm/sec. While this also solved the shrinkage warping, it did not work out as well for the top fill.

author: BluRocks

description.text:
Use your lungs to rapidly fire darts from Nerf magazines using this breech fed blowgun, or adapt the mechanism to your own homemade blaster.  The pump grip can be cycled repeatedly to load multiple darts for a shotgun effect.  
This toy can fire nerf darts at higher velocities and ranges than a standard Nerf blaster.  Eye protection is required to prevent serious injury.

In addition to the 3d printed parts, you will need:
6.5 inches of 2" PVC Pipe
6 inches of 5/8" x 1/2" flexible vinyl Tubing
3 feet of 9/16" x 5/8" Nylon Tube (Mcmaster #8628K57)
3 feet of "thinwall" 1/2" PVC pipe, (ID should be ~0.72")
16.5" of 1/2" Nylon Rod (Mcmaster 8541K18) or similar 1/2" plastic rod
8" of "thinwall" 3/4" PVC Pipe (ID should be ~.930")
1/4" Nylon Rod (Mcmaster 8541K14) or similar 1/4" rod
1x 1/2" CPVC T
1x 1/2" CPVC Elbow
1x 2" PVC T
6-32 screws in a variety of lengths
Some duct tape
At least one Nerf magazine, preferably the 18 round mags. Raider drums won't work. Print one of each piece except for PB4_WingGrip2a.stl -- you need two of those. The parts are in inches, so you will probably need to scale by 2540% Deburr the parts, drill out the large (clearance) screw holes to 5/32", drill out the small (pilot) screw holes to 7/64 and tap them 6-32. Ream the 1/2"-ish hole on the Airblock so that it's just barely big enough to slide in the 1/2" nylon rod without getting stuck, and Stockstarter just a bit more so that the nylon slides freely through the stockstarter. You may need to tweak the model to get useable hole sizes with your printer, most 3d CAD software will open the .stp assembly I have included. The length for PB4_WingGrip2a may also need slight adjustment to grip the Nerf magazines correctly. Use the illustrations as an assembly guide, note that the holes in the breech linkage (parts PB4_FrontGripLink and PB4_BackBreechLink) use set screws to stay fixed to the Nylon rods of the breech. The flexible hose is attached via a CPVC elbow to the air output. It's important to have the flexible hose between your mouth and the blaster to reduce the likelihood of a mouth injury in a case where the blaster is knocked towards you. The flexibility also helps with ergonomics. If the hose doesn't stay snug in the CPVC elbow, duct tape over it all to hold it in and improve the seal. The magazine squeezer (the almost elliptical part) will need clearance holes to be drilled matching the holes on the wing grips. There is no pilot, you have to measure and match up the holes by hand. The out stop is held to the barrel with duct tape, and the front grip tube is held to the front grip link with duct tape. Insert magazines with the breech in the back / retracted position, release magazines from same position by squeezing the ellipsoid at the small ends. Fire by blowing into the flexible tube with the breech in the forward position after having drawn it back and forth once. You can shotgun load and fire multiple darts by repeating the motion multiple times between firing.

description.text:
Used for Flames of War; modular bocage/hedgerow;

  • These are a (big fat) work in progress; they can take a little while to print; printed with very minimal support along the outer areas; use a length of filament to connect them together end to end or glue as needed.

  • They are about 3-4 inches in length; they can scale up a little larger if needed.

  • This is a mash-up of the vines, bloxen bramble and virus/proteosome model; I've also used the virus/proteosome models as smoke plumes in the past, if printed at the right scale and dry-brushed they look just about right.

  • I need to finish the bottom rubble base and some entry gates and possibly a t-section/angled-section. The rubble base isn't needed but adds a little height; The bottom rubble would be printed separately in black ABS and the bocage would be printed in green ABS followed up with some variations of brown/green paint colors.

  • Will probably play around with some polygon reduction to reduce the size and print time.

  • Paint as needed, use of flock isn't necessary but can soften the features. I based this somewhat on the OOP hedges from Miniature Building Authority; as seen on Ben's RPG Pile Hedge Maze Episode - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksvS0N9Chy8

description.text:
v2 of the Infill 3D Bowden .75 Geared Extruder, major change is that it uses a standard hobbed bolt vs the 1st version that used a smaller custom size hobbed bolt, there is other changes that at the moment I am forgetting.
I been wanting to do this for a while since a few people ask for it finally here it is.
Further updates will be found here https://infill3d.com/28-extruders

1x Pneumatic fitting 1/8 to 4mm
2x 688ZZ Bearings (Extruder)
1x 608ZZ Bearing (Idler)
2x M3 Washers (Springs)
2x M3X45 Socket screw (Extruder to idler)
4x M3X8 Socket screw (Motor)
2x M3X16 Socket screw (Idler)
4x M3 Nuts (Idler, spring screws)
2x 1/4" x 1/2" x .035" (6.350 x 12.7 x .889mm) Utility comp springs (Extruder to idler)
4x M8 Washers (Hobbed bolt)
1x M8 Nyloc Nut (Hobbed Bolt)
1x Hobbed bolt
Be careful when you are treading the pneumatic fitting is easy to strip that area, I wanted to beef it up but space is limited in that area. It works fine just be careful not to apply too much force that could strip the plastic.
When mounting the motor notice the notch on the big gear is there to give access to the screws of the motor align the notch with the screws holes.

Small ghost figure to be used with LEDs and a piezo element, driven by an ATtiny85 or whatever. The LEDs are connected to a PWM port, so that light effects are possible. The piezo element can be used as either input or output, so that the figure can respond to its surroundings. Total cost, including LEDs, wood, breadboard, piezo element and ATtiny, is somewhere around $10 / €7. The original idea of this figure comes from http://www.littlerobotfriends.com. Those 'Little Robot Friends' are probably way more complex and versatile, using a full blown ATmega328. This one, of course, is much more fun to build and to program.

• Print this design
  • Prepare two LED and fasten with hot glue
  • Fasten a piezo element with a dab of hot glue
  • Use double sided tape to fix the figure
  • Use two 22 ohm resistors in series with the LEDs
  • Connect ATtiny and battery box
  • Design appropriate software
  • Enjoy!
    • I've created the following Processing code, suitable for an ATtiny85 or equivalent: /*
    Source name: Interactive Ghost Figure
    Author: Rudi Niemeijer
    Copyright: Use as you like
    Description: Light and sound effects for interactive ghost
    Target: ATtiny85

RESET ADC0 PB5 x|1 ^ 8|x VCC (+)
PWM ADC3 PB3 x|2 7|x PB2 ADC1
PWM ADC2 PB4 x|3 6|x PB1 PWM
(-) GND x|4_____5|x PB0 PWM */ // Constants for Arduino
// const int speakerPin = A5; // pb2 on pin 7
// const int eyeLeft = 3; // pb3 on pin 2
// const int eyeRight = 5; // pb4 on pin 3 // Constants for ATtiny85
const int speakerPin = 2; // PB2 on pin 7
const int eyeLeft = 1; // PB1 on pin 6
const int eyeRight = 0; // PB0 on pin 5 // Generate a frequency of 1/period Hz with duration in ms
void beep(int period, int duration) {
for (int i = 0; i < duration; i = i + (period / 1000l)) {
digitalWrite(speakerPin, HIGH);
delayMicroseconds(period/2);
digitalWrite(speakerPin, LOW);
delayMicroseconds(period/2);
}
} // Duo-tone going up, LEDs light up as well
void siren() {
int t;
for (t = 440; t < 600; t++) {
beep((1000000/t), 5);
beep((1000000/(1040 - t)), 1);
analogWrite(eyeLeft, t - 440);
analogWrite(eyeRight, t - 440);
}
} // White-noise kind of sound, LEDs light up as well
void burst() {
int p, d, t, l;
l = random(5, 60);
analogWrite(eyeLeft, l 3);
analogWrite(eyeRight, l 3);
for (int t = 0; t < l; t++) {
p = random(1000, 2000);
d = random(1, 1);
beep(p, d);
}
delay(random(100,2000));
} // Scan the analog port for sound on the piezo element
void waitforSound(int timeout) {
int m = millis();
int val, knock = false;
int treshold = 90;
analogWrite(eyeLeft, 0);
analogWrite(eyeRight, 0); beep((1000000/440), 50); pinMode(speakerPin, INPUT); while ((m + timeout > millis()) and knock == false) {
val = analogRead(speakerPin);
if (val >= treshold) {
knock = true;
}
}
pinMode(speakerPin, OUTPUT);
beep((1000000/880), 50);
} void setup() {
pinMode(speakerPin, OUTPUT);
pinMode(eyeLeft, OUTPUT);
pinMode(eyeRight, OUTPUT);
siren();
} void loop() {
waitforSound(180000);
delay(1000);
siren();
delay(1000);
for (int i = 0; i < 30; i++) burst();
for (int i = 180; i >= 0; i--) {
analogWrite(eyeLeft, i);
analogWrite(eyeRight, i);
delay(50);
}
delay(30000);
}

title: Pi Supply Case for Raspberry Pi Model 2B and B+ with Opening Lid

description.text: We designed this case as a cheap and cheerful enclosure for your Raspberry Pi Model B+. It gives access to GPIO, DSI and CSI connectors as well as all of the other edge connectors and the SD card. It snaps together with no screws or other hardware - just six pieces of acrylic - for ease and speed of assembly. If you have no interest in making one of these yourself, but like the case, then you can always purchase one from our website at http://www.pi-supply.com - this also has the added benefit of supporting our future open source projects! Enjoy! License: All text above must be included in any redistribution. Please also make sure to include the text "Designed by www.pi-supply.com and shared under the CC-BY-SA license" on the laser etching of the case. If you sell these please do not use "Pi Supply" as the product name, customers will be confused!

This case should be cut out of 3mm acrylic if using a laser cutter.  
Alternatively you could 3D print it, but make sure you have a thickness of 3mm otherwise the case will not fit together.  
Be careful and gentle when assembling and dis-assembling the case. Acrylic is brittle and can snap quite easily if are too rough with it.

title: Simple Filament Spool using Aluminium Tube

description.text: Another filament spool design, using cheap aluminium tube. 6mm tube for the arms, 12mm tube for the axle - no bearings. OpenSCAD and STL files attached. Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13961

1) Print 3x spoolArms and 1x spoolHub.
2) Cut 6mm aluminium tube to suitable lengths - I used 180mm lengths to give an outer reel diameter < 300mm
3) Drill out the arm holes to 6mm
4) Insert aluminium arm tubes
5) Slide on plastic arms
6) Cut 12mm aluminium tube to suitable length for the axle - I used a leftover piece and suspended it above my printer using wire.
7) Load filament - easiest way is to slide one of the plastic arms against the hub, then loop the filament over other two arms and finally slide the last arm back out to hold the filament securely
8) Slide spool onto axle If it's a small reel of filament, then twist the arms sideways to hold the filament securely.

author: gswatts

description.text: This is a hexapod which is controlled using a Red Back Spider robot controller. You can watch it first steps at https://plus.google.com/photos/115565637042333354708/albums/5851147062342792113/5851147060153143554 NEW: beta code for arduino and android to control it is added to instructions.

The original files are completely rebuild.
The dxf (and svg) file for the tibia pin are included. The other parts are 100% openscad.
The servo's which are used are Hitec HS 645MG with Heavy Dutty HD-LS and HS 485HB with R-X Servo Arm (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42489). Openscad may have some problems to render the full hexapod. So i comments some parts and merged the full stl afterwards with blender. 12 645MG's are used for the tibia and femur. 6 485HB are used for the coxa's. All bolts are M3. All openscad files are included so you can create stl files for all individual parts, but the stl files are also included.
The main body (top and bottom, is split into 2 parts which can be joined in order to make it printable by a printrbot). If you want to create the stl's yourself, you have to build: Body Top
1 x body_split_1(true);
1 x body_split_2(true); Body Bottom
1 x body_split_1(false);
1 x rotate([0,180,0]) body_split_2(false); for the Left Legs: (all parts 3 times)
coxa_bottom();
rotate([0,180,0]) coxa_top();
translate([-40,0,5]) rotate([0,0,-30]) femur();
rotate([0,180,0]) femur(true);
translate([0,-200,0]) tibia_pin();
rotate([0,180,0]) translate([-70,-100,0]) tibia_counter(); Right Legs (All parts 3 times)
mirror([1,0,0])coxa_bottom();
rotate([0,180,0]) mirror([1,0,0]) coxa_top();
mirror([1,0,0]) translate([-40,0,5]) rotate([0,0,-30]) femur();
rotate([0,180,0]) mirror([1,0,0]) femur(true);
mirror([1,0,0]) translate([0,-200,0])tibia_pin();
mirror([1,0,0])rotate([0,180,0]) translate([-70,-100,0]) tibia_counter(); Code for Arduino and Android to control it: https://github.com/maartenweyn/DajiJug

description.text: I tried using the pillow block described in http://www.soliforum.com/topic/4824/how-to-forget-about-circle-problems-for-ever/, but unless it is printed and installed perfectly, I found it was binding the rod rather than supporting it. So I designed this "self adjusting" replacement with some wiggle room so the rod can guide exactly where it ought to be mounted.

Since the bolt holes in the base are bigger than an M3 bolt, the base can tilt a bit. By tightening the face plate holding the bearing to the face, the Y rod itself forces the base to be perfectly vertical. Then you can tighten the bolts holding the base to the solidoodle. After that you can loosen the faceplate so any stress caused by cranking down the base is relieved and re-tighten and the theory is the rod will now be perfectly supported. At this point, you can tighten down the Y motor and it shouldn't cause the rod to deflect as much.

title: Sliding Lid RAMPS 1.4 Box - Lower Profile

description.text:
After my original make proved popular and numerous requests for the files, I offer this re-mix. Reduced the height by 10mm, but increased the length by 10mm so I can mount the fan on the end plate instead. Moved the fan vents onto the end-plate and increased the size for a 40mm fan. Added the Gyrobot logo so it will not look out of place on my Dual Orca 0.43. There is something very Asimov about a machine printing it's own upgrades. My printer doesn't have the LCD screen so if you need exit channels for this then you are welcome to modify the OpenSCAD source file and upload the remix. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk
Modified OpenSCAD file attached, if anyone wants a further play.

description.text:
12mm camera rig base
need extra parts to assemble:
1\ d12mm pole with 250mm long x2
2\ M3x16mm screw with nut x2
3\ M4x16mm screw with nut x4

Final assemble look (upper side) Final assemble look (bottom side) Base arm part build instruction Please use higher infill for base arm part to get enough strength to hold the whole setup.
Normally 1~2kg after all parts assembled, include camera, rigs, magic arms and external monitor. The basic base is for 40mm width pan-fit. The big base is about 50mm in width.
Found it's difficult to fix in my Manfrotto video platform (MVH502AH) after build. some rework need to be done to done.

Tips in any amount are appreciated: https://www.paypal.me/satgod .223 Speed loader This version does 10rnds at a time
Simply slide onto your .223 mag
Drop 10rnds in
insert the plunger and push This also works with your ar15 7.62x39 CPD mags as well
and will load 8 rounds at a time
If you use it for 7.62 loading I recommend a HIGH infill
I did my from nylon and it performed flawlessly
if using abs or pla use a HIGH infill (50% at least)
as the 7.62 round is harder to push down
